qas.question: When was the Mint Act passed?
How many grains of silver did the Mint Act define the dollar as?
Who suggested that the ratio of silver to gold should be fixed?
What market value were gold coins traded in relation to?

answers.text: Congressional standard of the silver dollar

qas.question: In what year did the shift in gold standard occur?
When was the Standard Act passed?
How many grains of gold did the Mint Act define the dollar as?
Who suggested that the ratio of silver to dollars should be fixed?

plausible_answers.text: Congressional standard of the silver dollar

qas.question: What market value were other silver coins traded in relation to?
In what year did the shift in silver standard occur?

context: From <a0_0><b5_0>1792<b5_0/><a0_0/>, when the Mint Act was passed, the dollar was defined as <a1_0><b6_0>371.25<b6_0/><a1_0/> grains (24.056 g) of silver. Many historians[who?] erroneously assume gold was standardized at a fixed rate in parity with silver; however, there is no evidence of Congress making this law. This has to do with <a2_0><b7_0>Alexander Hamilton<b7_0/><a2_0/>'s suggestion to Congress of a fixed 15:1 ratio of silver to gold, respectively. The gold coins that were minted however, were not given any denomination whatsoever and traded for a market value relative to the <a3_0><b8_0>Congressional standard of the silver dollar<b8_0/><a3_0/>. <a4_0><b9_0>1834<b9_0/><a4_0/> saw a shift in the gold standard to 23.2 grains (1.50 g), followed by a slight adjustment to 23.22 grains (1.505 g) in 1837 (16:1 ratio).[citation needed]
